review_title: AVOID. You can do better elsewhere.
pros:
Nice quiet border town within an hour reach of some larger amenities and basic outdoor activities.

Decent health benefits. Not the best, but okay.
cons:
Lowest Paying Faculty Positions in the USA.

Management claims to be all compassionate and caring, but they are the exact opposite. The moment you start having problems, they come down on you in the most authoritarian fashion. There is no Due Process here, just dictate and punish. Once you start getting your balance, they pull the rug out from under you without cause or warning.

It is like the 1960's all over again, with support from the original 60's. Students have unbridled support to make up baseless claims against any professor or instructor they wish. Students actively scheme in the hallways against anyone they do not like, and management supports this activity. Your job, in whatever capacity, depends on being popular with the most spoiled and hyper-sensitive of students. 

Baseless or blatantly false accusations are placed into your permanent record without you being given a chance to review or rebut them. Do yourself, your family, and your reputation a great favor: AVOID SDSU AT ALL COSTS.

pros: A good place to work part time as a student.  Great management, fun engaging atmosphere.  Most employees are also students and they are very flexible with work hours.  You will also have many opportunities to meet people in the remote sensing industry.
cons: The pay is low and the benefits are none existent.   This is also most likely a job that you can only work if you are a student at South Dakota State University.  As a result there is a very high turnover rate as students graduate.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Crossroads, TX
pros:
1- The university offers many scholarships a year to help many students of different disciplines all over the world to pursue their future career. 
2- The new system of paying educational fees is better than before.
3- The ability to transfer your credits from other universities or from degree to another degree (i.e, master to PhD) is a great benefit that relive the financial and social burdens over the students.
cons:
1- Most of these scholarships are based on teaching, not research, assistantships that will give the students less time to conduct their scientific research.
2- The health insurance based on these scholarships is not helping the students a lot and too expensive especially for older students
3- The scholarship is not suitable to support married students.

review_title: It all depends on who you work with, and pay is not good
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Brookings, SD
pros:
1. Nice people, from boss to co-works are very friendly;
2. Brookings is nice place to live.
cons:
1. The above statement for pros #1 is only true to myself, I know a handful of Graduate Assistants being used like slaves by their advisors or department, or both. It really depends who you work with, and your own personality.
2. The fact that Graduate Assistants needs to pay their own tuition is ridiculous: in most universities in US, this would not happen. 
3. For professors, the administrations are willing to spend money building constructions and polish the campus, but not willing to increase pay. Many valuable professors were lost in recent years and what we got left is just a beautiful campus.

review_title: SDSU--you'll get a fair shake and a safe community
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Brookings, SD
pros: Reasonable faculty and administration, well-behaved (usually) and respectful students, safe place to live--SDSU is the premier land-grant university in the immediate region, and one of the highest-quality higher ed locales in the Midwest. Something of a diamond in the rough, especially given that the town of Brookings is an enjoyable place to live for most people.
cons: As in the cons other than the normal laundry-list of infuriating issues working at a university in the 21st century (e.g. administrative bloat, mismanagement of funds, lack of proper respect for teaching faculty over research faculty, etc. etc. etc.)? The South Dakota winters are pretty hard and Brookings can be a bit limited if you're not looking for a safe place for your family to live.

review_title: South Dakota State University is a political clout of racially biased, bullying seniors in faculty circle
pros: Brookings a nice small town, schools are good and community is small. If you like small town then it is a good choice.
cons: if SDSU is your job destination then welcome to hell! They discriminate new faculty for their race. Administration speaks one language of idealism when trying to capture students but when it comes to teaching, it doesn't even provide basics. Highly understaffed, Senior faculty bullies juniors to the extent that they yell at them, insults them and administration stands with seniors.

pros: The faculty, staff, and research mentors all work closely with the students in not only research work but also preparation for presentations and written documentation. Research students are always given a schedule of events at the beginning of each week so that they know what to expect. On-campus housing and travel reimbursement is given at the beginning of the program. There is a research stipend. Overall it was a great research experience.
cons: I do not have any complaints from this program. There is a level of professionalism, kindness, and respect from the faculty to the research students that was greatly appreciated.

review_title: Good place to start, but no growth opportunities
pros: The biggest pro is enjoying my coworkers. Also, the University was more stable during times of low economy than many businesses; I was hired during the recession.  SDSU is a good place to start, or for those looking to stay in the same position.  If looking for growth and opportunities, look elsewhere.
cons: The politics within management is obvious and frustrating for those it affects.  Very little support for professional growth and development.

job_title: Program Assistant I in Brookings, SD
pros: The state has good vacation and sick leave.
cons: The pay is very low and the rent in town is much higher than expected.  The state also separates Civil Service Employees and Professional staff.  This involves separate meetings, awards, etc. and basically just makes the CSA employees feel like a lesser group.  Even though the state has distinctions, the university shouldn't. There are a lot of VP's and higher executives making $100k plus while they pay the CSA people hardly anything.

job_title: Undergraduate Assistant Maize Geneticist in Brookings, SD
pros: At South Dakota State University, I worked in bio-stress. I worked under a maize geneticist. I enjoyed a flexible work schedule, and gained valuable labratory and work experience. I worked there as an undergraduate.
cons: Cons. The only con I can really think of is that Brookings, SD fairly far from a major city excluding Sioux Falls, SD which is 40min away. I actually enjoyed this fact. I went to school near some excellent hunting and fishing.

review_title: Poor pay and lack of diversity.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant, Athletics in Brookings, SD
pros: Not a challenging environment, so jobs are relatively easy competed to other higher ed settings. People are nice.
cons: Not an intellectual environment. Zero diversity. The few people of color on campus are international. Many years behind in terms of technology. Extremely resistant to change. Average school, but behave as though they are Ivy League. Whoever sticks around the longest gets promoted.

pros: Most of the students are friendly and willing to work fairly hard for a good grade.
cons: There is open discrimination of those who have disabities.  There is extreme workload placed on those with Masters Degree so that those who are doctorally prepared can become tenured.  Those who are doctorally prepared are expected to carry a heavy load also. There are those who document untruths on performance evaluations so that others resign.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Brookings, SD
pros:
Tuition waiver.
It is a great experience if your interests are similar to the research subjects
cons: It depends on what kind of professors you are working with. It seems like there are some good professors but in my case, it was horrible because my professor required me to work more than in the contract. In the contract, I was only required to work for 10 hours a week but the professor always wanted me to work a lot more than that. And the department could not help me in any way.

review_title: Wonderful platform for research work in Electrical Engineering.
pros: Safe and cool environment for research work. Professors are helpful. Student can choose their subjects according as their interest and does not matter what their previous background.
cons: University is too expensive compared to assistantship. Students need to cover their fees, insurance and acomodations themselves. Full Assistantship is too low. And Most of the students get half paid assistantship, no matters how much they work.

review_title: Great Job to work while a student in college
job_title: Technical Support Analyst in Brookings, SD
pros: Flexible work schedule, decent pay, only open during the week. Coolest boss I've ever had or heard of was Ronnie, best guy to work for and learn from hands down.
cons: Lack of growth opportunities, upper management can be bureaucratic about little things such as ordering more flash drives, or buying extra screwdriver sets, but that comes with working in the public sector.

review_title: Gender and Racial Discrimination is Common at SDSU
pros: some good research minded people
cons: The administration from top to bottom or bottom to top is completely management focused. There is no Leadership anywhere. Many deserving women faculties are not given the opportunities as their male colleagues are given. A few female positions are puppets under male managements. It is not a good place to thrive and grow. If you like to succumb, be discriminated for the gender (apply to female) and in many department you won't see a single person of diversity holding senior position and all decisions are made by 2-3 white guys. If anyone is considering to come to this campus even to work as a part of administration they should seriously think before it. They will be only used as a tool and when their use is over, they will be thrown out unless the person coming in is political. This is not a place that bring any research prosperity or satisfaction to work for. The paycheck is higher compared to anywhere in nation not because they hire best though because the best never comes here and if ever it comes, it leaves as soon as they. I know many faculties in Agricultural sciences, chemistry & biochemistry, dairy sciences and other who have left at very senior positions. This campus is worst place to work in the US. Apart from this Graduate students have the tough time as well, lack of supervision is the beginning of long list, financial support is inadequate compared to the cost very high living in Brookings, SD (thanks to the over inflated real-estate market - low-income house - food stamp price gouging). Irrespective of one being either a agriculture science/ dairy science/ chemistry/ biochemistry faculty if the person is apolitical and unless he isn't the part of inner clout of corrupt and manipulating administration that person has no chance to survive. senior faculty belittling, bullying, discriminating their juniors is a common practice and one that is very encouraged by senior in departments and by senior management. The unwritten but often practiced rule of SDSU is that as soon as a new faculty joins the campus, they should be made to fail and leave. Good luck to all those who wish to go to SDSU and think that they will do a great science!

review_title: Ph.D. level graduate student. Both Teaching and Research Assistant.
job_title: Graduate Teaching/Research Assistant in Brookings, SD
pros: Very understanding administration. Flexible hours.
cons: No benefits or insurance. It can also be difficult to find a dissertation advisor or research topic; one is left to attain these without much guidance upon entering the program.

review_title: Nice place to work, but probably not to stay unless you have a Ph.D.
job_title: Senior Programmer Analyst in Brookings, SD
pros: Friendly and collaborative environment (at least when I worked there). Cozy campus and town. Plenty of sick days. State pension program still in existence.
cons: Low salary. No WFH options in most cases. Advanced degrees are required for many positions where a bachelors degree and industry experience should suffice, restricting upward mobility. Parking is limited.

pros: South Dakota State University has a great community and offers great experience for students while they are still attending college.
cons: The only down side is that students are only allowed to work so many hours and they are not enough for students who have bills to pay. There for the students have to sometimes have second jobs while being a full time student.

pros: Being a learning assistant was beneficial because it felt good helping students with their home work. It was also nice to have a review of past course work while tutoring.
cons: The biggest con was that it was boring at times. Since most classes are on computers, most students could be help from the online tutorial.
